description: Dive into "Shibuya's Hidden Gems: Explore for Free" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Shibuya's Hidden Gems: Explore for Free

places.generalDescription: The Odaiba area in Tokyo is home to a replica of the famous Statue of Liberty, located on an artificial island in Tokyo Bay. Standing at approximately 12 meters tall, this iconic landmark has become a popular tourist attraction. Visitors can enjoy a wide range of activities in Odaiba, including relaxing at Odaiba Seaside Park and Beach, experiencing a hot spring at Oedo Onsen Monogatari, and exploring various museums and entertainment venues.

sources.snippet: The Odaiba Statue of Liberty is the Tokyo based Statue of Liberty, sitting just outside Daiba Station, in Odaiba Kaihin-Koen park. The statue is 1/7th the size of the New York Statue of Liberty, and was originally intended to be a temporary fixture to the Tokyo waterfront, as a symbol of the friendship between Japan and France ‚Äì Much like the New York one to symbolize the friendship between the U.S.A and France. The Statue was only supposed to last from 1998-1999, but due to the popularity of it, it soon became a permanent resident of the Tokyo Waterfront.
sources.shortName: 12 FREE things to do in Tokyo

places.name: Statue of Liberty - Odaiba

reviews.text:
My day was supposed to end in TeamLab Planet (see that review) but while waiting for my reservation time, we walked Odaiba. It is a very beautiful place, and close to the beach you will find the Japanese version of the Liberty Statue üóΩ. Oh yeah, you did not expect that, very cool. We spend some time walking on the sand, enjoying the view, taking pics of the Statue.
From this place to team lab walking would be like 45 minutes, a little bit long but YOUR BODY need exercise.
Well with not further, see my pics and vids.

Visiting the Statue of Liberty in Odaiba gave me the same feeling I had over 10 years ago in New York. It brought back memories and felt surprisingly familiar. The area is absolutely stunning during sunset, the colors in the sky, the view of the bridge, and the peaceful atmosphere made it one of the most relaxing moments of our trip.

Highly recommended if you're looking for a scenic and chill spot in Tokyo! ‚ò∫Ô∏è‚ò∫Ô∏è‚ò∫Ô∏è

It is one of the must-visit photo landmarks for anyone heading to Odaiba. While it's not as grand as the one in New York, the Tokyo version has its own charm, especially with the stunning background of Rainbow Bridge and Tokyo Bay. On a clear day, the view is absolutely gorgeous.

There's some viewing decks and benches nearby, perfect for sitting back and soaking in the seaside and cityscape. Whether you're a couple, a family or solo, it's a great place to stroll, snap some memorable photos, and just enjoy the vibe.

And if you time your visit around sunset, you're in for a treat. The golden glow reflecting off the water and the statue creates a dreamy scene. Once night falls and Rainbow Bridge lights up, the whole area turns into a romantic postcard.

With tons of shopping malls nearby, you can easily spend the whole day here. Shopping, sightseeing, and snacking all in one go!

places.address: 1 Chome-4-2 Daiba, Minato City, Tokyo 135-0091, Japan

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Tokyo, Yoyogi Park is a sprawling urban oasis that spans an impressive 134 acres. This vibrant park features serene lakes, charming fountains, and lush forested areas adorned with mature trees, making it a perfect escape from the city's hustle and bustle. Located just south of Shinjuku and near the iconic Yoyogi National Gymnasium, it's easily accessible for both locals and tourists alike.

sources.snippet: The 54-hectare park which is the 5th-largest in the city is divided into an A Zone which is a central park with fountains and a forest walking path, and a B Zone with a soccer pitch, an athletic field, a concert stage, sports facilities and an event hall. Entry is free so anyone is able to enter. There is a wide grass field within the central park with its fountains, and on a good day, it‚Äôs great to just bask in the sun all day without needing to do anything or take that stroll among the trees and feel nature.
sources.shortName: Six Shibuya Sightseeing Spots | GoWithGuide

sources.snippet: It all happens in Yoyogi Park, from Elvis-impersonating rock and roll dancers to rabbits out walking on leads in their Sunday best, skateboarding dogs, live music, and massive Hanami parties in cherry blossom season. It is one of Tokyo‚Äôs biggest parks, with expansive lawn areas, huge old shade trees, ponds, and forested areas. Although it doesn‚Äôt have massive plantings of cherry trees or autumn colour, it does have a dramatic display of both in the right season and is a popular place to visit.
sources.shortName: 20 fun things to do in Shibuya, Tokyo

sources.snippet: Another pleasant park in the middle of Tokyo, Yoyogi Park is a large green space that features wooded areas, trails, ponds, and lawns. It has nice pathways for walkers, runners, and cyclists, and also a dog park section where you can watch canines of all shapes, sizes, colors, and breeds having some fun time. In the spring and autumn seasons, it sees crowds and crowds of people wanting to get the best seats for cherry blossoms and autumn foliage viewing.
sources.shortName: 15 FREE Attractions to Check Out in Tokyo -
26 Unreal Things to do in Shibuya, Tokyo [Day + Night]

sources.snippet: Yoyogi Park, spanning 54 hectares, is a verdant oasis in Shibuya that's perfect for families with kids. Famous for its cherry blossoms in spring and vibrant autumn foliage, the park showcases seasonal natural beauty throughout the year. The park offers bicycle rentals, including children's bikes, making it an excellent activity when visiting Shibuya with kids.
sources.shortName: Best Kid-Friendly Places in Shibuya: Top Spots for Family Fun and Adventures

sources.snippet: Yoyogi Park is one of the largest parks in Tokyo, situated in the north of the Shibuya district. The park consists of spacious lawn areas, ponds, and forested areas, which are perfect for outdoor activities. Besides, the park holds various seasonal events throughout the year, and it‚Äôs a very popular cherry blossom viewing spot during the sakura season.
sources.shortName: 28 Best Things to Do in Shibuya 2025

sources.snippet: Located between Harajuku and Shibuya, the bustling Yoyogi Park is a hangout for locals and tourists alike. Yoyogi is one of Tokyo‚Äôs largest parks and it is perfect for a stroll after the craziness of Harajuku or Shibuya. We loved spotting the adorable dogs, the street artists and the fun atmosphere at the weekends!
sources.siteName: The Whole World Is A Playground
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to do in Shibuya Tokyo (2023)

sources.snippet: Yoyogi Park is one of Tokyo‚Äôs most popular and largest parks. Located near Harajuku station and Meiji Shrine, visitors can easily walk across to the park after doing some exploring at these other attractions. It is a vast space, popular with locals who you will see exercising, walking their dogs and having picnics.
sources.shortName: 10 Must Visit Spots in Shibuya

sources.snippet: As one of the largest city parks in Tokyo, you should include Yoyogi Park in your Shibuya sightseeing plan. Come spring, the park becomes a charming place where you can view cherry blossoms in their full splendor. Check out the ginkgo tree forest which transforms into an intense golden colour during autumn.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Things to do in Shibuya [2024]

sources.snippet: Yoyogi Park is one of Tokyo‚Äôs well-known parks, and it is a good spot for morning jogs or picnics by the pond. During weekends, you can watch street performers like the Rock and Roll Dance Group ‚Äì Roller Family. They wear 50s fashion, sporting denim on denim and brushed up hairdo, dancing to 50s music.
sources.shortName: Best Things to Do in Shibuya: Your Ultimate Travel Guide | Japan Travel by NAVITIME

sources.snippet: Yoyogi Park is one of Tokyo's largest and most popular public parks. It is a vast green space with ponds and forested areas in the heart of the city. The park is a hub for recreational activities such as jogging, picnicking, sports, and dog-walking, and it‚Äôs often very busy with people on weekends.
sources.shortName: The Best Free Things to Do in Shibuya

sources.snippet: Maybe you‚Äôre traveling with your family and need to get away from the hustle and bustle of the big city. Then, a peaceful stroll through the Yoyogi park is just the thing for you and your family. Located just a 3-minute walk away from Harajuku station, this is one of the largest parks in Tokyo.
sources.shortName: Top 20 Things to Do in Shibuya

sources.snippet: Shibuya‚Äôs famous Yoyogi Park is one of the best places to get a little greenery in your scenery. Sit by the cool, calm waters of the central pond and recoup, or explore the expanse of the green green grass. You can traverse across the fields or keep to the concrete paths for a stroll.
sources.shortName: 10 Things to Do in Shibuya | things to do in Shibuya at night| things to do in Shibuya Japan

sources.snippet: Escape the concrete jungle and find solace in this urban oasis. Perfect for picnics, strolling, or practicing your yoga. During these warmer months, the park is always sprinkled with visitors chilling on their tarps.
sources.shortName: Discover 20 Free Things to Do in Shibuya!

sources.snippet: Yoyogi Park, one of Tokyo‚Äôs largest parks, hosts a large number of cultural festivals each month. For instance, there‚Äôs the Brazil Festival, Philippine Festival, and the Thai Expo, among others.
sources.shortName: 18 Best Things to Do in Shibuya

sources.snippet: 2-1 YoyogikamizonochoShibuya City, Tokyo, JA 151-0052+81 3-3469-6081. Yoyogi Park, about 134 acres in size, is beautifully landscaped. It is a local favorite for outdoor fun and entertainment.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Tokyo, Japan (for 2024)
25 Best Things to do in Shibuya, Tokyo (2019)

places.name: Yoyogi Park

reviews.text: A nice park to relax in or go for a jog.  Most of the park is tree lined paths and bench areas though it has a few extra sections.  There is a beautiful butterfly garden on the south side that I'd recommend.  A herb / rose garden.  A dog park.  And a lake for viewing birds... Though they were hiding during our visit.

Green, expansive, gorgeous. There are so many words that could describe Yoyogi Park but those are my top three. I loved the greenery, art, wildlife, and the First Flight Monument. Easy to get to, easy to navigate. Even though we walked around for a few hours, there was still more to see. Don't miss it!

Photography by Jason Taylor (Except for the pictures I took)

This park does not have a lot to offer but this is one good place to spend some time off, peaceful "me time" and have picnics with your loved ones. This is just a 5 minute walk from the Meiji Shrine. By the time I visited, Roses are in bloom making the park more interesting to visit.

places.generalDescription: Cherry Blossoms Garden, located in Tokyo, Japan, is a serene and picturesque destination known for its stunning cherry blossoms that bloom from mid-March to early April. Amidst the city's skyscrapers and technological marvels, this garden offers a peaceful retreat with wide walking trails and abundant natural wildlife. Visitors can immerse themselves in the beauty of the cherry blossoms while enjoying the tranquil atmosphere filled with sounds of birds and insects.

sources.shortName: 12 FREE things to do in Tokyo

places.name: Cherry Blossoms Garden

reviews.text:
A beautiful and quiet, relaxing park with long wide walking trails plenty of scenery natural wildlife to enjoy. There's some sounds from the city but mostly the sound of birds and insects, almost a serene feeling being here.

I took some pictures of the cherry blossom tree garden "outside of season" (non-bloom) to show the contrast and suggest to consider the potential these trees have to look so beautiful in their moment during a certain time of year but are not much to look at when it's not their season or time.

Remember that everyone has their season! üôèüèªüòáü§ç This was a beautiful place to visit and contributes to deep thought and introspection.
Very peaceful and beautiful garden. The cherry blossoming is just starting, it should be beautiful in a few days when it's at full blossom

oyogi Park, located just a short walk from Harajuku Station, transforms into one of Tokyo's most enchanting spots during cherry blossom season. As spring arrives, the park's wide-open spaces come alive with vibrant shades of pink and white, drawing locals and travelers alike to celebrate hanami-Japan's centuries-old tradition of flower viewing.

Unlike the more crowded cherry blossom locations such as Ueno Park or Shinjuku Gyoen, Yoyogi offers a more relaxed and spacious setting. Large grassy areas, shaded paths, and open fields make it ideal for picnics, group gatherings, or solo walks under the sakura canopy. On weekends, you'll see friends sharing bento boxes, families lounging on picnic mats, and photographers capturing the fleeting beauty of the blossoms.

One of Yoyogi's charms lies in its versatility. While the cherry trees are the seasonal highlight, the park's natural scenery, scattered ponds, and proximity to Meiji Shrine make it a multifaceted destination. Musicians, artists, and street performers add a cultural touch, creating a festive yet peaceful atmosphere.

Facilities like clean restrooms, food stalls, and trash disposal points are well maintained, making it easy to spend several hours comfortably. Arrive early to secure a good spot, especially on weekends, as locals often stake out space before noon.

In short, Yoyogi Park during sakura season is a quintessential Tokyo experience-calm, colorful, and deeply cultural. It's a beautiful contrast to the city's urban rush and a must-visit for anyone seeking to enjoy cherry blossoms at a slower, more meaningful pace.

places.generalDescription: "Â±ã‰∏ä„ÉÜ„É©„Çπ SHIBU NIWA" is a free public garden located on the top of a building in Shibuya. It offers a stunning view of the bustling Shibuya crossing, making it an ideal spot for capturing beautiful pictures, especially during the evening when it is beautifully illuminated. Accessible from the 12th floor, visitors can enjoy an open and spacious feeling while taking in the panoramic views.

sources.snippet: Despite being a free place to visit, to understand the magnitude of the activity of the Shibuya crossing, it has to be seen from above. There are plenty of viewpoints to do it, but not many of them are free. My favorite one is Shibu Niwa, a public ‚Äúgarden‚Äù at the top of a nearby building.
sources.shortName: 17 free things to see and do in Tokyo

places.generalDescription: Rainbow Bridge is a stunning suspension bridge that spans Tokyo Bay, connecting Shibaura Wharf to Daiba. Opened in 1993, it serves as both a transportation route and a beloved landmark for the new Tokyo Bay area. The bridge features vibrant nighttime illumination powered by solar energy and offers a walking route along its 1.7 km length.

sources.snippet: The Tokyo Rainbow Bridge is a stunning structure that spans across Tokyo Bay, connecting the city‚Äôs central district with the man-made island of Odaiba. Completed in 1993, the bridge has become an iconic landmark in Tokyo and a popular destination for tourists and locals alike. You can walk on the underside of the Rainbow Bridge for free, which in itself is a pretty unique attraction.
sources.shortName: 12 FREE things to do in Tokyo

sources.snippet: Along with the Odaiba Statue of Liberty, Rainbow Bridge is a symbolic structure in Odaiba that brings in visitors by the mass. This suspension bridge connects the beautiful waterfront between Odaiba and the Tokyo mainland. Unfortunately, only a few people know that you can not only take pictures of it from a distance but also walk across this landmark at no charge!
sources.shortName: 12 Best Free Experiences in Tokyo

sources.snippet: Extending about 800 meters across Tokyo Bay, the Rainbow Bridge is highly recommended to anyone who loves nice and scenic leisurely walks. From sunset to night time, the views of the bay and the city from it are incredible, and make for amazing photos. Walking the entire length from either the Tokyo side or the Odaiba side takes under half an hour.
sources.shortName: 15 FREE Attractions to Check Out in Tokyo -

sources.snippet: Australia has Harbour Bridge, England has London Bridge and in 1993, Japan built their own bridge in Tokyo and named it Rainbow Bridge. You have to make sure to take a walk across the truly beautiful Tokyo Bay. The bridge is an easy walk, but be warned, you do have to share the bridge with traffic so it isn‚Äôt the quietest of walks.
sources.siteName: TokyoTreat: Japanese Candy & Snacks Subscription Boxes
sources.shortName: The Top 5 Free Attractions in Tokyo!

places.name: Rainbow Bridge

reviews.text: The Rainbow Bridge in Tokyo is a stunning architectural marvel and a must-see attraction. Spanning Tokyo Bay, it offers breathtaking views, especially at night when it's beautifully illuminated. Whether you're walking, driving, or taking a boat tour, the bridge provides a unique perspective of the city's skyline. The pedestrian walkways are perfect for a leisurely stroll with picturesque scenes, making it a favorite spot for both locals and tourists. Highly recommended for anyone visiting Tokyo!

This is definitely something to see the bridge itself looks stunning specially at night when the lights turn on, do keep in mind that if it's not a holiday, the lights will only shine in white or purple. Otherwise, if it's a holiday, it will be a rainbow color. I recommend taking pictures of it or watching it from the Statue of Liberty.

I was staying in Odaiba, and walking across the promenade of the rainbow bridge was an amazing way to get to the Tokyo tower.
The bridge is a great design and is a real focus point of the surrounding area.
It's great to look at it, but if you get the chance, I would definitely recommend walking across.
